entry.title: Painting 5
entry.content:
Previous painting related posts are about the subjective element in the cognition of artistic value in an art-object, Bildakt theory, the new figurative painting genre and how the artform evolved by the introduction of photography. The following is about the nature of beauty in art, and personal beauty in representational paintings specifically.

The Nature of Beauty in Art

A work of art is an artifact of a kind created, with artistic intention and upon presentation to be attributed artistic value by an authoriative entity on the matter of arthood, or so I claim [1]. This definition does not contradict that there could be a more essentialist mechanism, but respects the possibility that there is an essential uncertainty in what constitutes art.

Art is part of a sociocultural system, thus there is no definition independant of the public that is part of it. The authority, on a societal level, are the people or institutions ascribed the role of arbiter by the system, like museums, art critics and the media, or on a smaller scale a person respected for their judgments of taste within a social circle. As a consequence, while the taste in art may be highly subjective, in theory not all judgements of taste have the same validity. Kant argues that a genuine judgment of taste ought to be disinterested, not rely on subjective idiosyncrasies even including human desires, in which case it reaches a state of objective validity. Kant’s criterion to reach an objective judgement does not contradict David Hume’s criterion of value in art, the ‘test of time’ from his 1757 essay, ‘Of the Standard of Taste’, or idea of a proposed class of critics that are able to find objective beauty. In practice problems arise, because disinterestedness is not extrinsically observable and there is little incentive to honor sentiments contradicting one’s own if there is little at stake as in the mundane valuation of art [2].

“But where there is such a diversity in the internal frame or external situation as is entirely blameless on both sides, and leaves no room to give one the preference above the other; in that case a certain degree of diversity in judgment is unavoidable, and we seek in vain for a standard, by which we can reconcile the contrary sentiments.” — ‘Of the Standard of Taste’ by David Hume [3]

With artistic value, we define an umbrella term for all values the artifact can possibly exibit, that aid its acceptance by the artworld authority as art. As identified in previous posts, a pluralistic conception of artistic value is required to better understand the appeal of artworks [4]. Art might reward a person’s contemplation of its aesthetic properties like beauty or harmony as pleasurable fulfulment of a need, or it might offer alternative perspectives and sentimental value via the subjective cognition of the art-object.1 For example, in traditional Western painting primarily concerned with representational modes of production, it can be agreed upon that arranging for an artwork to be perceived as beautiful can make for a meaningful contribution to the artistic value qua aesthetic value contributed; injected into the relation between work and onlooker.

Kant, in his 1790 work “Critique of Judgment”, identifies free and dependent (also named adherent, conditioned) beauty, whereby representational painting and human beauty are mostly defined by their dependent beauty characteristics. With the claim to subjective universality via a judgement of taste, dependent beauty is defined by its evaluation that presupposes a concept of the thing under examination, thus an idea of what it is supposed to be [4], [5]. Under this premise, it fulfills its function and we can conclude that “The beauty of representational paintings arises when a painting is beautiful as a representation of something.” [4]. The contribution to artistic value from dependent beauty is thus further spread between appearance properties of what is shown, i.e. a landscape, a cityscape, or person, and the presentation itself; the latter is influenced by the onlooker’s appreciation for the quality of craftsmanship, composition, rendition, and the surroundings of the art-object.2

In recent decades, much pointed to an emerging field of research to explain what may guide the ideals of beauty [5], [4]. In the 1980s, at the peak of the cognitive revolution pioneered by thinkers like Noam Chomsky, there emerged the view that rather than regarding the mind as a blank slate to be inscribed with cultural values, it is regarded to mechanistically function as information processor with innate values for interests and tastes initialized via evolutionary processes like natural selection [6]. Evolutionary psychology combines evolutionary theory with cognitive psychology and claims authority in questions of personal aesthetic preferences, seemingly legitimized by natural science. In my opinion, evolutionary psychology has been used as a tool by bigots to justify social unequalities and the status quo, because this almost pseudo-scientific field is inviting to just-so stories in which the argument is only based on its internal plausability and rought ideas about prehistoric humans, hence can be argued eather way to further one’s point of view. Evolutionary biology shows that adaptation is just one part in evolutionary variation occurance next to mutation, recombination, and genetic drift, wherein natural selection does not need to play a role in developing mundane features [7]. Whereas the explaination of the quantitive research results via evolutionary theory might not be falsifiable, the findings can be applied to a certain extent, so let us narrow the focus and consider a realistic portrait painting with its rigid convention of form, wherein dependent beauty will be dictated by the personal beauty of the individual representend to a large degree. Various studies attempt to find general preferences in human biological traits like degree of averageness, symmetry, sexual dimorphism, ocular topography, or neoteny by considering participants responses, to evaluate beauty and make physiognomic deductions.3 But coming back to Hume, these are all sentiments, not judgments, as their subjectivity is not accounted for and there is not really a way to remove this noise floor.

“Vainly would we […] endeavour to enter into the sentiments of others, and divest ourselves of those propensities which are natural to us.” — ‘Of the Standard of Taste’ by David Hume [3]

There is no reason to believe that the mean of sentiments can lay claim to lasting, objective truth. Agreeable predictions can be made for a general population, so not all is misguided about evolutionary psychology and quantitive research looking to yield general trends in preferences of physical attractiveness, but they certainly cannot claim the fidelity required to reasonably dictate the understanding of personal beauty in representational portrait painting, or the practice of creating the aforementioned.

The attempt to quantify beauty in the above manner is unsatisfactory because it reduces beauty to its givenness and utility, it reduces the distance between the narcissistic ego and the other through its self-centered attempt to understand and find value in its consumption [8]. True beauty in art is a resistance to the erosion of otherness. In “Agonie des Eros”, Byung-Chul Han identifies that one cannot love the other who has been deprived of otherness, but only consume it. As Eros [and beauty] are a relation to the other that is placed beyond abilities of reason and the faculties of mind, it follows that if one could possess, please and recognize the other, it would not be the other. Possessing, recognizing, grasping are synonyms of the aforementioned abilities [9].

Painting as a Free Time Activity

At the turn of the 20th century, conditions for workers improved and the concept of “free time” extended from the wealthy few of the leisure class to the regular workers [10]. Adorno points out that genuine freedom does not have to follow from having free time, because of what occupational labour demands of us, we are subconsiously forced to alter what we do with our free time, caused by exhaustion and atrophy of creativity (thats why amateurs create superfluous paintings, as he claims). People resort to hobbies, “a pursuit outside one’s regular occupation engaged in especially for relaxation” to cope, which is an unfree use of free time, as it becomes an extension of work or adaptation to work in that case.

While work increases the objective value in the world and is thus exchangeable, a genuinely free leisure time activity is indifferent to that and is intended to create value for the actor and not others, be it society, the employer or the leisure industry. This does not mean that no objective value can be created in the process, or even an absence of activity and work, as there is such a thing as “working by way of leisure” [11]. But Adorno does not consider that people have to work, so an unproductive, “mindless” use of free time to aid their work may be required. Being free from the hobby ideology is a priviledge; you can only be free and be “working by way of leisure”, if your energy is not bound by your labour. And you can only reflect on your lag of freedom via your use of free time, when you have the time and freedom to do so, thus many people will not even realize that they are caught up in this pattern.

It is also not clear how to determine what a truly free activity is, because even sport is put into question by Adorno, as “The accepted reason for playing sport is that it makes believe that fitness itself is the sole, independent end of sport: whereas fitness for work is certainly one of the covert ends of sport.” [12]. For the act of painting, the question becomes at what point the painting is product of hobby activity and when of work by way of leisure; which is ultimately a question about its quality and objective (intersubjective) value, a rather futile endeavour. Regardless of whether that condition is met, I personally do not consider painting merely a hobby, since I have invest nontrivial amounts of time, both the free and should-have-been-spend-on-other-things kind and it, at times, just feels too much like working.

For the first time, I also build a custom frame to match the painting.

Framing and Displaying Paintings

Frames can possess more than mere utility; beyond protecting works from environmental factors, they exhibit and enhance artistic value of the Gesamtkunstwerk [total work of art] [13]. Of particular interest in this regard is the Artist frame, created or designated for a specific painting by that painter. Depending on the type of frame envisioned for the work, the artisan craft of framemaking will require experience and access to adequate woodworking and specialty equipment. The carving of specific moldings from strips of wood, cutting glass, gilding, and application of composition ornamentation (compo) may be unfeasible without a workshop equipped for these tasks and a certain throughput of frames to justify the purchase of all the bulk materials.

Regardless of who made the frame, in order to prevent damage while achieving the aforementioned benefits, risks associated with framing and displaying paintings must be mitigated by follwing established conservation best practices.4 Although picture framing glass is not normally used to protect oil paintings, it can be beneficial to their long-term conservation if careful consideration is given to the change in air and temperature conditions the work experiences. Outer frames with a matching wooden mat, perhaps linen-covered, as a spacer between the painting and the glass are an unusual but attractive display option.

Minor Colorimetry Update

We previously discussed a method to generate a spectral power distribution (Spd) for a given sRGB value [16]. I since came up with a new conversion method that uses an artificial neural network, trained on a public dataset [17], to find the Spd. The average valuation loss in terms of root mean squared error is $2.645\times10^{-2}$, but I am sure it could be improved with further hyperparameter tuning.

The plots visualize the available dataset in RGB color space. As we can see, there are areas without ground truth data, but they are out of range of natural painting subjects and the pigments used in oil paints. Thus, the model accuracy for those values is not relevant for this application. For comparison, we can roughly see the colors present in this painting.

entry.title: Painting 4
entry.content:
Let’s canvass some more canvases. This post contains a continuation of colorimetry basics, introduced in the last post. The new painting is ekphrastically filigreed, and techniques for its production are explained.

Colorimetry

While the introduction to colorimetry by example of an approximation method for spectral reflectance curve generation from sRGB values brought us closer to the goal of calculating mixing ratios of paints for a given color, even less than $0.1 \%$ of pigment weight variation within a mixture can have a visually substantial impact in my experience. In this application a high level of precision is required, one that the previously presented spectral matching method does not offer, especially once we consider that the result has to improve one’s ability beyond what can be achieved by traditional practice of mixing.1

If we partition the visible range, limited by the narrowest spectral bandwidth that presents a noticeable difference in hue, experiments show that the needed threshold can be as low as 1nm around 500nm and 600nm, meaning a radiation’s wavelength shift of 1nm would result in detectable chromatic differences.[1] Thus, for oil-colorant formulation we need to consider a method to subtractively mix optically thick turpid media with suspended non-luminous light scattering pigment particles; the current state of the art for this setting is the two-flux Saunderson-Kubelka-Munk Model.[2]

The paint is based on a translucent medium, usually linseed oil or safflower oil, which is rendered optically thick by inhomogeneously dispended, colored pigment particles of a size about one order of magnitude larger than the visible wavelengths; consequently all incident light will be Mie-scattered over multiple wavelength-dependent diffusion and absorption events, and completely diffuse along the direction of the incident light ray so that only considering the ascending flux of reflection $\Phi_{\uparrow i, \lambda}(s)$ suffices.

The two-flux Kubelka-Munk mixing law describes the spectral reflectance $R_{i,\infty}(\lambda)$ at the surface $s=0$ as the ratio of fluxes, and by assigning each internal turpid layer-element $ds$ that the light moves through a probability of photon absorption $K(\lambda)$ and photon scattering $S(\lambda)$ that are characteristic of the wavelength and pigment mixture encountered2, as long as the ray does not reach the substrate, i.e. the canvas, as a function of those two coefficients for each pigment type.

\[R_i(\lambda) = \frac{\Phi_{\uparrow i, \lambda}(s=0)}{\Phi_{\downarrow i, \lambda}(s=0)}\] \[\frac{K(\lambda)}{S(\lambda)} = \frac{(1-R_{i,\infty}(\lambda))^2}{2 R_{i,\infty}(\lambda)}\] \[\frac{K_{mix}(\lambda)}{S_{mix}(\lambda)} = \frac{\sum_j c_j K_j(\lambda)}{\sum_j c_j S_j(\lambda)}\]

With addition of Saunderson’s Equation (including specular reflection component), $R_{i,\infty}(\lambda)$ equates to a function of reflectance measurements $R’(\lambda)$, while also considering light source specific Fresnel reflection at the air-paint border $\rho_0(\lambda) \approx \frac{(n(\lambda)-1)^2}{(n(\lambda)+1)^2}$ and internally $\rho_i(\lambda) \approx 0.68\cdot n -0.56$, where $n$ refers to the refractive index.

\[R_{i,\infty}(\lambda) = \frac{R'(\lambda)-\rho_0(\lambda)}{(1-\rho_0(\lambda))(1-\rho_i(\lambda))+\rho_i(\lambda)R'(\lambda)-\rho_0(\lambda)\rho_i(\lambda)}\]

Starting from reflectance measurements $R’(\lambda)$, we are able to calculate possible mixtures of pigments with hitherto unknown concentrations $c_j$, that can match a target spectral reflectance by characterizing each pigment’s $K_j(\lambda)$ and $S_j(\lambda)$ coefficients, leaving the mixing law equations to be solved for $c_j$ only.

Characterization is initialized by finding the four unknown coefficients of two pigments, usually black and white, by assigning $S_W = 1$, and finding the rest via spectral reflectance measurements of three compositions; masstone white (W), masstone black (K), and a mixture (KW) where $c_K=3\%$ and $c_W=97\%$.

\[\begin{aligned} S_W =& 1\\ K_W =& \frac{M_W}{S_W}\\ K_K =& - \frac{c_W(M_W - M_{KW})}{(1-c_W)(M_K-M_{KW})}M_K\\ S_K =& \frac{K_K}{M_K} \end{aligned}\]

For each additional pigment (C), two more measurements are required; either a mixture (CW) where $c_{CW}=5\%$ and $c_W=95\%$ for organic pigments, or a mixture (CW) where $c_{CW}=25\%$ and $c_W=75\%$ for inorganic pigments, and a second mixture (CK) where $c_{CK}=99\%$ and $c_K=1\%$.

\[\begin{aligned} S_C =& \left\{ \frac{(1-c_{CK})[M_{CK}S_K-K_K]}{c_{CK}} - \frac{(1-c_{CW})[M_{CW}S_W-K_W]}{c_{CW}} \right\} \frac{1}{M_{CW}-M_{CK}} \\ K_C =& \left\{ \frac{(1-c_{CK})[M_{CK}S_K-K_K]}{c_{CK}M_{CK}} - \frac{(1-c_{CW})[M_{CW}S_W-K_W]}{c_{CW}M_{CW}} \right\} \frac{1}{1/M_{CW}- 1/M_{CK}} \end{aligned}\] \[M_{X} = \frac{(1-R_{i,\infty, X}(\lambda))^2}{2 R_{i,\infty, X}(\lambda)}\text{ where } X\in \{K, W, KW, CK, CW\}\]

By using the obtained absorption and scattering coefficients for reflectance matching, we find the best physically fitting combinations of pigments that can be further evaluated and optimized with colorimetric methods, like metameric matching and color difference specifications.

If the below equation is satisfied, which is rarely the case, an exact solution was found. In other cases, the solution is evaluated by calculating the spectral reflectance from the results and comparison to the target by finding the root mean square (Rms).[1]

\[\sum_{i=1}^{n\text{ pigments}} c_i \left[ K_i(\lambda_j)-S_i(\lambda_j)\frac{K_{mix}(\lambda_j)}{S_{mix}(\lambda_j)}\right] = \sum_{i=1}^{n\text{ pigments}} c_i Q_i(\lambda_j) = 0\]

Not only is finding an exact solution unlikely, we also still need the reference reflectance data, that for example belongs to an sRGB value, and the illuminant present, to optimize the found mixture of pigments.

Techne

Goethe said “You can only see what you know.” [“Man sieht nur, was man weiß.”], thusly a painting’s perception can change with additional information and artwork is never completely seperable from its creator. A descriptive work of poetry that relates to an artwork through rhetorical devices will not be able to replace, but may be able to enhance the painting by adding information and context. The poem “Edward Hopper and the House by the Railroad (1925)” by Edward Hirsch [3] about the eponymous painting is a good example for this so called ekphrastic poetry, a common practice since the greek antiquity. Playing with language to draft poetry is enjoyable, finding the right words almost feels like solving cross-word puzzles, but it does require a lot of courage to share amateurish attempts, thus offering a slightly more prosaic examination of this post’s painting ex infra will have to suffice.

In juxtaposition to Hirsch’s stanzas and Bildakt theory, by considering the interaction between beholder, painter and painted object/subject, this work too could be said to deal with the gaze, looking and being looked at. Under this premise, one can read into the painted figure, a sense of frustration for it is instrumentalized to serve, and be evaluated by, the gaze of both painter and beholder. At the same time, as a passive object, the painting has no agency. In an evenly lit white void as if placed in a display window, forced to be beheld by onlookers to be only one among thousands of impressions, to satisfy the compulsive act of sedating the mind with an all-too-fleeting distraction. Art-objects as pseudo-subjects are acted-upon, suffer from a strong power asymmetry defined by the artistic and aesthetic conventions of objectification, this applies to figurative painting depictions in particular.

Because the paintings have little impasto, they are suitable to be scanned by a regular document scanner. The harsh, direct lighting offered by these scanners is the biggest downside compared to a daylight photograph; this makes the scans unusable for display purposes, but allows for a very detailed mapping of the painting. There is no lens distortion, or changes in lighting condition, and a 1200dpi scan at $30\times40cm$ result in a resolution of 268 megapixels. Parameters derived from a scanned color checker card can be reused indefinitely, making scans comparable over time.

On a side note, an oil painting is traditionally comprised of multiple layers of paint. The opacity of paints is too low, and even the lightest brush’s brushmarks too deep, to achieve the desired palette mixture’s masstone with just one coating of the ground, naturally I was looking for a good method to preserve the mixed colors, for reuse and unoxidized reference at a later stage. Oil paint aging happens because of oxidative polymerization, creating a molecule network, and oxidative degradation, which forms unlinked molecules. After this first stage, hydrolysis follows in both cases which can make the paint vulnerable to extraction of those smaller molecules by solvents, depending on the amount of degradation it experienced. [4] That is to say, there is no aging without oxidization, an environment which can be created in an airtight container with oxygen scavenger sachets, made of a mixture of iron powder and sodium chlorite.

The plan is to store mixtures in tiny zip lock bags and store those in an air-tight container with an oxygen remover, in the expectation that the paints will remain unchanged. When I tried this preservation method over a period of about a month, there was some stiffening of the paint, but that should already be enough time for the underlying layer of paint to dry enough to paint another one. It is not perfect, but to quote Nam June Paik, „When too perfect lieber Gott Böse“.

Endnotes

[1] C. Oleari, Standard Colorimetry: Definitions, Algorithms and Software. 2015.

[2] P. Kubelka and F. Munk, “Ein Beitrag zur Optik der Farbanstriche,” Zeitschrift für technische Physik, vol. 12, pp. 593–601, 1931.

[3] E. Hirsch, “Edward Hopper and the House by the Railroad (1925),” 1925. [Online]. Available: http://english.emory.edu/classes/paintings&poems/house.html

[4] K. J. van den Berg, A. Burnstock, M. de Keijzer, J. Krueger, T. Learner, and A. de Tagle, Issues in Contemporary Oil Paint. 2014.

  1. I did implement a complete algorithm from rgb to mixing ratio, it is able to identify different primary colors, but that is about it. It was a lot of work but the results are just too vague, still glad I tried. ↩

  2. For example, yellow pigment has strong tinting in low wavelengths under 530nm, thus mixing with black pigment lifts the mixed paint until about 520nm (green wavelength) and then flatens because black starts to dominate, resulting in a greenish color. ↩

entry.title: Foreign Language Area Studies
entry.content:
Since the 1970s, Foreign Language and Area Studies (Flas) scholarships have been funded through the US’ National Defense Education Act. This post attempts an axiological discussion of area studies, second language acquisition and the interdependence of these prima facie disjoined subject areas.

By introducing this topic, I am expanding the established network of thought presented on this website, to further interlink seemingly independent subject areas, as this often leads to innovative ideas.

The Case for Area Studies

A promising way to link previous considerations of art and sports to area studies is to look at their common evaluative aspect. Axiology connects aesthetics with area studies via ethics when introducing area studies via Rawls’ Theory of Justice. Ethics addresses questions of morality, which in turn assigns a value to human behavior. This assignment is according to moral values and norms that are, as I propose defying normative ethic’s contestations, culturally and temporally relative; defined by a group, society or culture. Good moral character is considered most beneficial to society.

Rawls states that “character can be molded by antecedent circumstances” and people “acquire a desire to act justly, and to do so for the right reasons, when they have lived under and benefited from just institutions”.[1] A just society causes its constituting citizens to flourish, it induces existential meaning and an interest to act morally; in that sense character is subject to moral luck. A trait that helps to propel this feedback mechanism is a virtue, such as participating in the civil public’s deliberations to weigh interests not your own. Area studies offer a pure form to exercise this virtue and add to a moral character and just society via the taken civic responsibility. By the holistic engagement with other cultures and societies within the global landscape one creates and fosters a set of virtues for a transareal citizen.[2]

Area studies as a discipline has been criticized for being too specific and detailed without scientific concept building or generalizing; merely telling stories by accidentally stumbling into the examined regions’ otherness. This putative weakness, a researcher in “Rebirth of Area Studies” argues, is a strength since “the fact that we not only study ‘otherness’ but often find ourselves through our travels and our readings in foreign languages to be an ‘other’”.[3] As I hypothesized above, this engagement could be conducive to good character development; second language acquisition in particular is known to increase “tolerance of ambiguity”.[4]

Second Language Acquisition

Communication by language is a form of information transmission used to transfer thoughts. Speech norms are thus a necessary condition for cultural exchange. The so called Sapir–Whorf hypothesis further states, that at least linguistic relativity is a given and influences of language feed back into thought creation, hence second language acquisition (Sla) is a necessary condition for fully understanding a foreign culture with a distinct language.

Linguistic theories about language learnability and acquisition can be divided based on their stance regarding linguistic nativism. Neurobiologically minded approaches conclude that, “at this time there is no convincing evidence for domain-specific circuitry for language.”, hence speaking for general nativism and putting a damper on Noam Chomsky’s Universal Grammar Theory.[5] During Self-regulated learning (Srl), setting goals and choosing suitable learning techniques is elementary, the foci of second language learners should thus be geared towards applied linguistics’ empirically verified language learning techniques instead of more general, philosophical hypothesis, if the goal is efficient L2 acquisition.

The declarative/procedural model supports both general nativism, as well as the general approach taken by linguist Stephen Krashen, because it has been shown than “learning to identify relatively simple parts of language, such as words, is facilitated by effortful learning, whereas learning more complex aspects of language, such as grammatical features, is impeded by effortful learning”.[6] The former equates to declarative memory, learning of language morphology—word roots, affixes, conjugation, etc.—mentioned in the latter would be helped with procedural memory system usage. Both immersion1 and deliberate practice[8] have their place.

Stephen Krashen’s approach focuses on compelling, comprehensible input in form of free voluntary reading [9] —meaning the extensive type— that is effective when around 98% of vocabulary in the input text is known.[10] The spaced repetition learning approach is based on the spacing and testing effect studied in psychology. Long-term potentiation in neuroscience denotes a type of persistently amplified signaling between neural circuits, and is cited as an underlying factor for the validity of the mentioned phenomena.[11] Spaced repetition is what active recall over increasing time intervals is called, and is a promising optimization of memory capability.[12] [13] The mental work done during active recall is most effectively used when one is just about to forget what one has learned—this is usually the case with increasing time intervals.[14] Spaced repetition software (Srs) has been in development since the 1980, to implement an optimal utilization of this effect. In 1987, Piotr Wozniak implemented the first algorithm for computer-based flashcards with SM-2, which modern popular options like anki are largely based on.[15] [16] Since the exact forgetting intervals can at most be approximated stochastically, an adaptation of these must be transmitted by the user with reference to the concrete remembering success for each card; pell-mell execution will not work, deliberate practice is imperative.

Flashcards based on a frequency dictionary’s word list derived from an appropriate corpus assures targeted initial vocabulary acquisition. For initial grammar acquisition, reading through frequency sequenced sentences exhibiting different grammatical structures, like example sentences from a grammar workbook is helpful. As a next step up from corpora based on subtitles, that belong to the Subtlex movement and are more aligned with spoken language than the traditional text based corpora, tools like Subs2Srs can be utilized to generate flashcards of sentences from subtitled content.[17] Epub formatted eBooks too can manually, or rather likely via regular expressions, be converted into Srs readable format, paving the way towards extended reading. Generating narration from these book passages with Tts engines, like coqui-tts for python, could assist focus while reading and improve listening comprehension. Interactive conversation with large language models (Llm) and usage of neural network based translators will likely amount to a paradigm shift in how and for what reason languages are learned in the near future. I imagine Sla will be less important for communication, and become even more about virtue signalling like sports competitions.

The significant interplay between target language and its associated culture has been laid out above via Rawls and area studies.

entry.title: Information Management
entry.content:
Personal information management (Pim) can be helpful to—via the intention of repurposing the collected semantic information—create something worthwhile in the future.

But knowledge management certainly also has a negative connotation due to its misguided usage in the milieu of status-seeking productivity-optimization and self quantification; as an end in itself.[1] A tendency of information hoarding may also be a sign of self-justification of excessive distraction seeking via information consumption. Nevertheless, the notion of writing to forget, or let go of thoughts and ideas, alone could substantiate such practices as practical release valve as long as one is aware of the rationale behind them.

Information Science

As an individual’s personal space of information (Psi), now increasingly shifts from the physical to the digital, and with growing importance of human–computer interaction (Hci), digital Pim[2] becomes the main resource for information keeping and Pkm. As knowledge is only indirectly manageable,[3] Pkm is regarded a subset of Pim and should, for my taste, also utilize spaced repetition to facilitate learning as its primary objective. With that, Pim also involves the cognitive science fields of problem solving and decision making.

Within information science, the field of Pim is unique in its self-directed nature, curation and retrieval of items is done by the same entity. The user-subjective approach describes the need for flexibility of a given system to adapt to its user, enabling incorporation of various information fragments into a single structure. Primacy effect[4] and the active categorization required are most likely responsible for the preference of Pim-system design into folder trees and its traversal via navigation, in contrast to search functions, tagging, or relationship graphs. Information fragmentation is a problem exaggerated by the ever increasing amount of information items created and amount of external services used, thus the ability to export user data has to be a prerequisite. Digitization of non born-digital assets can be performed to consolidate the Psi.

Information Management

File Management

File Management is about designing systems for information and data preservation. Data preservation is concerned with present time data loss prevention and thereby protection of privacy, but also goes beyond that by anticipating usablility, integrity and other potential data object changes in the future. Data loss prevention is a prerequisite for further preservation and is most basally implemented with a backup scheme.1 Future-proofing is ensured by using established standards for file management structures and file formats to make renderability more likely and future retrieval more convenient. Further, time-tested and widely used Foss often has a higher chance of maintained development in comparison to proprietary software alternatives.

Implementing hierarchical folder-tree structures, analogous to the use of universal decimal classification (Udc)[5] and Ddc in library classification demands compromises in content allocation edge cases, but rewards with reduced infrastructure maintainance work and clarity. If decimal classification is used to name certain classes of files that can actually benefit from it, it has to be considered that for most file managers, numerical sorting is the default, meaning 5 < 22 < 100. This has to be disabled, as the numbers in this scheme are used as if they were decimals, hence .100 < .22 < .5. Grouping in decimal classification follows defined categories, the need for interlinking notes, as is required with nonhierarchical relationship graphs, wikis or tagging systems, is limited. Traversing the distance between two related nodes within the data structure should minimize involvement of ancestors.

There should be content type dependent file naming conventions. For sorting purposes, the most relevant metadata is stated first. While books could be named via UDC - Title - Author - Year, others types may be sorted by initializing the filename with Iso–8601 (2021-11-12). Choosing the correct date to associate with a file can be tricky in some cases, for example consider a video shot in 2000, published in 2012 and introduced to the Psi in 2020. Plain hierarchical folders are not the best fit for all applications, they can however be expanded to serve as storage location for, hence working in conjunction with, tag editor generated databases to the benefit of image categorization.

Studies advocate for the GrayArea concept [6], [7]. A GrayArea is implemented as a gray area in each folder, enabling relevance classification of data into a third state between keep and delete by graying files out. Personally, the concept of GrayArea seems like a bad one, because you simply shift the issue around. I nonetheless use an auxiliary-folder named !tmp, that can be used as an incorporation buffer for files violating naming conventions, with the distinction that its temporal aspect is eponymous. With regular backups, and versioning being taken care of, the caution threshold for removing data is lowered to break the tendency of overkeeping.

Notes and Annotations

Since plain text is the most flexible, writing in a lightweight markup language, in this case Markdeep-js markup syntax, is the best option. Markdeep allows writing browser-accessible html documents in an extended markdown syntax, with the caveat that browsers do not support XMLHttpRequest to the local file system or shell.openPath(), so files from the local file system cannot be opened by the browser with a local application 2. Over time, however, simply reading and writing these files in a text editor proved to be the most practical, making its ability to generate html somewhat obsolete. Even for personal notes, having a certain standard in relation to style and reference management will ensure they can contribute to potentially distributable assets 3.

Reference Management

Output generation like non-fiction writing is build upon a foundation of curating and validation checking sources. A structured information input, as shown in the graph, facilitates this. One has to be aware that this can make consumption seem more productive and worthwhile than it probably is, just because you create a record of it does not mean that it was worth your time. The file naming conventions for different content types from file management result in the ability to convert a list of filenames with regular expressions to a desired metadata format. XML is the lingua franca for serialization of information, other formats suffice when the given file’s conversion to a pandas dataframe or manipulation with regular expressions is straightforward, as is the case for .csv and .bib files. Thusly, tools to be utilized are required to offer those export schemes. The biblatex format is a good option in combination with the Jabref reference manager and the pandoc document conversion software used to generate various types of output documents from the notes and references. In libraries, the subject cataloging facilitated by decimal classification is usually augmented with controlled vocabulary tagging, e.g. Library of Congress Subject Headings or GND (Gemeinsame Normdatei). While this is helpful for information retrieval, it has a high maintenance cost as biblatex is far from ideal for this application. Defining a custom bibliography style for custom entry-types and -fields is very involved, but would be necessary to keep the records in line with other authority files (wikidata, GND). Bibliographic records can be hierarchically structured into work, expression, manifestation and item (WEMI). Biblatex is designed to cover only the manifestation subset.

On the plus side, in mp3tag, the audio file metadata tag editor, a custom export filter can be defined to export albums as entries to biblatex format.

$filename(bib,utf-8)

$loop(%albumartist%,1)
$loop(%album%,1)
$puts(NumberOfAlbums,$add($get(NumberOfAlbums),1))
@%contentgroup%{%contentgroup%_$put(val,$add($get(val),1)),
  author           = {{%contentgroup%_$put(val,$add($get(val),1)),
  author           = {{%artist%}},
  date             = {%year%},
  publisher        = {%label%},
  title            = {%album%},
  subtitle         = {%title%},
  totaltracks      = {%totaltracks%},
  file             = {:%_directory%/%_filename_ext%:%_extension%},
  genre            = {%genre%},
  creationdate     = {%_date%},
  modificationdate = {%_date%},
}
$loopend()
$puts(TotalAlbums,$add($get(TotalAlbums),$get(NumberOfAlbums)))
$puts(NumberOfAlbums,0)
$loopend()

In Jabref too, custom export templates can be created to export data as desired. These two cover most content types adequately with the notable exception of images. digiKam is a FOSS image tag editor to organize images, what it lacks is a way to export a spreadsheet of image metadata from the populated database. This is useful if storing tags within the file, or doubling the file count by using XMP sidecar files is undesired. By default, digiKam stores metadata in the digikam4.db sqlite database. There are no custom fields or any kind of build-in metadata export in digiKam, thus it is not a perfect solution. The following generates a table with filenames and associated tags.

-- !!! Generate a table with filename and corresponding tags from digikam4.db
-- this table has the tagid and the corresponding tag name
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS t1 AS 
SELECT tagid, name 
FROM ImageTags 
INNER JOIN tags ON tags.id = tagid 
GROUP BY tagid;

-- this table replaced imagetags.tagid with the tag name
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS t2 AS 
SELECT imageid, name 
FROM ImageTags 
INNER JOIN t1 ON ImageTags.tagid = t1.tagid;

-- we concat the tag names that belong to an image id, and show the filename for each image id
SELECT images.name AS 'FileName', GROUP_CONCAT(t2.name, '; ') AS 'Tags'
FROM t2 
INNER JOIN images ON images.id = imageid 
GROUP BY imageid;

-- we remove the temporary tables 
DROP TABLE t1;
DROP TABLE t2;

For more on output generation consider the document design post.

Endnotes

[1] J. Murphy, “Personal Knowledge Management is Bullshit,” Apr. 27, 2022. [Online]. Available: https://www.otherlife.co/pkm/. [Accessed: May 03, 2022]

[2] W. Jones, Personal Information Management. 2007.

[3] W. Jones, “No Knowledge but through Information,” 2010. [Online]. Available: journals.uic.edu

[4] H. B. William Jones Abe Wenning, “How Do People Re-find Files, Emails and Web Pages?” Mar. 01, 2014. [Online]. Available: https://doi.org/10.9776/14136. [Accessed: Feb. 19, 2023]

[5] UDCC, UDC Universal Decimal Classification. Abridged Edition. 2003.

[6] O. Bergman, “It’s not that important: Demoting personal information of low subjective importance using GrayArea,” 2009. [Online]. Available: journals.uic.edu

[7] O. Bergman, The Science of Managing Our Digital Stuff. 2016.

[8] W. Strunk, The Elements of Style. 1918.

  1. We can use rclone to create an off-site crypt remote for syncing the backup data to almost any cloud provider. For privacy there is no way around the rclone provided additional zero knowledge end-to-end encrytion (E2EE) layer; even with this protection it is scary enough already. No less than two additional encrypted on-site versions should exist, one of them offline and air-gapped (32110 rule). These storage partitions could be encrypted with VeraCrypt, which also offers pre-boot authentication for system drives. Finally, all backups need to be regularly audited for errors and the data (and passwords) recovery procedure has to be reviewed. We could add a second encryption layer and advanced backup functionalities like file versioning by using rclone with restic. ↩

  2. A solution would have been building an electron app, which I did as a proof of concept, but it felt like an overcomplication as a text editor with markup language files really ought to be enough. ↩

  3. Personal writing does not have to be copy edited, but general styling should be consistent regardless of publication state.
    “The Elements of Style” by William Strunk Jr. is a style guide about best practices in orthography, rather than typography.[8] As nonnative speaker, I certainly will continue to make some of the common errors discussed, but it is a helpful reference book. ↩

entry.title: Painting 3
entry.content:
Ex infra ponders whether alterations in a painting’s formation process can optimize its potential value and functionality, as properties assigned by the beholder.

Episteme

Paintings as products of culture are influenced by trends, novelties and current affairs shaping its substantiating society. Considering movable easel-paintings gradually superseded wall-painting’s dominance only in the 14th. century, just like all representations of artistic expression, paintings are neither in form nor in subject a cultural constant. Akin to a sport’s contrived rules, constraining properties of forms of art are a feature. Unleashed from church walls, artists could use their easel-paintings to trade, establishing an art market with the feudal lords as new clientele, then broadening to the middle class after the French Revolution.[1] Not long after, in 1839, invention of the Daguerreotype photographic process presents the low-cost and time efficient alternative of portrait photography to painted portraiture. Democratization of pictorial media by this novel imaging method naturally impacted the conception of a painting’s function and its placement in the hierarchy of art forms by their significance.

Adorno’s essay “Kunst und die Künste” argues, that though the new is not eo ipso better, even the weak manifestation of willingness to modernize bears more productive force than resistance to zeitgeist. Therefore painters have no choice but to deal with the crisis of meaning modern technology presents.[2] For Adorno, by its aesthetic properties, art suggests meaning within the meaningless.1 The meaning behind art and a definition of a work’s aesthetic properties were pondered in earlier posts, but considerations about creating an environment encouraging these characteristics seems like a useful addition. Perceptibility of aesthetic properties can differ between art forms, one might be more susceptible to certain stimuli. Thus distilling a form’s unique component, that constitutes this incalculable property, should catalyze assignment of meaning and distinctability in its functioning among the arts.

In the hope of finding an answer, I read several painting related chapters, including “Malerei als »Diskursarena« und als Kunst” in “Kunst und die Künste”. Rather unexpectedly, the conclusion about how a painting mechanistically functions turned out to be very in line with what I came up with in “Painting #2”.2 The author identifies three actuators compounding to a painting’s entirety. Physically manifested as a continuous planar object, the painting ground is covered with paint introducing, from a praxeological perspective, indexicality with a reflexive referral to the authorial entity [Handschriftlichkeit]. From a medium perspective, the canvas is filled in with color, to create the illusion of reality; despite no reference in the essay, I would equate this point of view with the Bildakt theory, the emergence of an aesthetic subject within the art-object. Can we deduce a practice for adjusting paintings to optimally utilize this structural make-up of actuators?

According to art critic Clement Greenberg, a focus on a painting’s flatness defined the evasive maneuver artists undertook from the mid 19th century up to the contemporary art movements of the 1970s to cope with photography, to stay distinctive and relevant. It rid itself from the veil of sculptural illusion, by self-critical reevaluation redefining the modern painting’s understanding of the self. Abstraction, closer to arbitrary object but more unequivocally modern and unique than ever before, in painting is not the end of the story. A contemporary art movement often called Photorealism started in the 1960s and is diametrically opposing the previous centuries trends and supposed enlightenment about what a painting ought to be.

Painting seeped into popular culture, the plethora of resulting opinions questioned the practice of art criticism itself.

“Nothing was clearer than the inadequacy of the then-going critical apparatus.” —[4]

Contemporary artists almost seemed to purposefully invalidate the canonical body of analytical theories with their work. The Photorealists’ aim to reproduce objects indistinguishable from a photographic depiction of the subject matter, appeared void of purpose and meaning; no style, no Handschriftlichkeit. This interpretation inhibiting literalness emanates visual objectivity but ambiguity in meaning, often interpreted by the beholder as a task to simply recognise the aesthetic encountered in everyday objects. Validity of this analysis is only given under the presumption that photographs, and by proxy their attempted painstaking duplication in oils, are objective. Photographs are neither transparent, because they do not necessarily show what they mean, nor are they—as subject to selection—objective. Photorealism’s ostensible neutralism is ultimately a critical examination of contemporary visual mass media’s assumed objectivity and verisimilitude.

Truly, photorealism is an unfitting term for this genre of new figurative painting, this invitation to juxtapose reality and its illusionary recreation; works not striving for perfection and “ideological indeterminacy”, but upon closer inspection questioning reality by making objective imagery—in Weinberg’s words—“strange”.[4] Redefinition as new figurative painting allows expression of the psychological moment of the individual painted and its sincerity as the thematic focal point, while photorealism undermines such dimension.3 Certainly not exclusive to painting as an artform, its permutability nevertheless appears to be its most essential asset and reason for the art world’s continuous assignation of relevance to painting. The future might hold a renaissance of Handschriftlichkeit—marks of ragged manual labor turning desirable—as reactive response to AI generated art, questioning not the objective, but the calculable. A permanent shift towards digital painting as the next evolutionary step is also possible; time will tell.

Colorimetry

As we concluded above, the intermingling of painting related analog and digital production processes will only increase. For painting it is crucial to understand how human color perception works and how colors are transformed and represented from the analog to the digital and vice versa.
The human eye can perceive color via excitement of three types of cone cells, called long, medium and short. The cones are concentrated in the fovea centralis, the observer’s field of view can be standardized by only accounting for the response of a certain area on the retina around the fovea. Common norms include the Cie 2° and Cie 10° standard observer. The Lms tristimulus values are the integration over the product of the spectral power distribution (Spd) of the light that meets the eye, and the cones’ spectral sensitivity for a given visible wavelength.[6]

\[L = \int_\lambda \Phi (\lambda) L (\lambda) d\lambda\] \[M = \int_\lambda \Phi (\lambda) M (\lambda) d\lambda\] \[S = \int_\lambda \Phi (\lambda) S (\lambda) d\lambda\]

The retina’s cells send these stimuli as chemical signals through the optic nerve to the brain. This Lms color model is the most basal of objective human vision representations, however it does not qualify as a color appearance model (Cam), as those go beyond mostly quantifiable measures and attempt to take into account more subjective perception parameters influencing a color’s appearance as interpreted by the brain. The Cie 1931 Xyz model, defined decades before the understanding of the visual processes in the eye, is also able to represent all possible cone cell responces, making it analogous to Lms by the Hunt-Pointer-Estevez conversion matrix.

\[\begin{bmatrix} X \\ Y \\ Z \\ \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 1.91020 & -1.11212 & 0.20191 \\ 0.37095 & \phantom{-}0.62905 & 0 \\ 0 & \phantom{-}0 & 1.00000 \\ \end{bmatrix}_{HPE} \begin{bmatrix} L \\ M \\ S \\ \end{bmatrix}\]

The Xyz model is useful, as it can be converted into the Cie 1931 xyY model, where Y gives the brightness of a color, and the xy plane the chromacity in the Cie 1931 xy chromaticity diagram.

\[x = \frac{X}{X+Y+Z}\] \[y = \frac{Y}{X+Y+Z}\]

While the diagram encompasses all visible colors, a real world reasonable-effort hue reproduction is limited by the choosen primary colors spanning a gamut in the xy-plane. Cie 1931 Rgb is one of such limited color spaces that by metamerism can reproduce a large subset of hues with just three monochromatic sources for the theoretical reference illuminant E, defining its white point and assigning a constant Spd for all visible wavelengths. Another Rgb colorspace is the web standard sRgb with the reference illuminant D65. To convert sRgb to Xyz, we first have to normalize, then linearize the vector’s values, done by inverse sRgb companding.[7]

\[\vec{v}_{rgb} = \begin{cases} \frac{\vec{V}_{RGB} }{12.92} & \text{if } \vec{V}_{RGB} \leq 0.04045 \\ \left(\frac{\vec{V}_{RGB} +0.055}{1.055}\right)^{2.4} & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\]

The conversion matrix can be calculated with the following coordinates in the xy plane for the sRgb color model.[8]

\[\begin{Bmatrix} x_r & y_r & x_g & y_g & x_b & y_b & X_{2°} & Y_{2°} & Z_{2°}\\ 0.64 & 0.33 & 0.3 & 0.6 & 0.15 & 0.06 & 0.95047 & 1.0 & 1.08883\\ \end{Bmatrix}\] \[\begin{align*} \begin{bmatrix} X\\ Y\\ Z \end{bmatrix} &= \begin{bmatrix} {S_r \frac{x_r}{x_r}} & {S_g \frac{x_g}{y_g}} & {S_b \frac{x_b}{y_b}} \\ {S_r} & {S_g} & {S_b} \\ {S_r \frac{1 - x_r - y_r}{y_r}} & {S_g \frac{1 - x_g - y_g}{y_g}} & {S_b \frac{1 - x_b - y_b}{y_b}} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} R\\ G\\ B \end{bmatrix}\\ \text{ with } \begin{bmatrix} S_r\\ S_g\\ S_b \end{bmatrix} &= \begin{bmatrix} \frac{x_r}{x_r} & \frac{x_g}{y_g} & \frac{x_b}{y_b} \\ 1 & 1 & 1 \\ \frac{1 - x_r - y_r}{y_r} & \frac{1 - x_g - y_g}{y_g} & \frac{1 - x_b - y_b}{y_b} \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \begin{bmatrix} X_{2°}\\ Y_{2°}\\ Z_{2°} \end{bmatrix} \end{align*}\]

Now, Xyz values can be converted to spectral reflectance curves for the D65 illuminant thanks to the methods presented in the paper “Numerical methods for smoothest reflectance reconstruction” by Scott A. Burns.[9] The paper’s third method is also referred to as “Least Hyperbolic Tangent Slope Squared (Lhtss) algorithm” on the author’s website. By, what I could gather, using the mathematical optimization method of Lagrange multipliers, the minimum of the first derivative squard of the function is numerically approximated via Newton’s method until the tolerance condition is met. $T$ is a matrix for the Cie 1931 2-deg physiologically-relevant fundamental color matching function (Cmf) according to Stockman & Sharpe (2000).[10]

\[\min \sum(z_{i+1} - z_i)^2 \text{ such that } T \left(\frac{\tanh(z)+1}{2}\right) = \vec{v}_{XYZ}%is it v_XYZ?\]

You, the attentive reader, might wonder what the point of this section could be. The paper proposes a method for calculating an approximate spectral reflectance curve from sRGB values. By fitting the spectral reflectance of a set of oil paints to this function, it may be possible to calculate ideal color mixing recipes, minimal palettes and waste less paint trying to match the specific colors of a reference picture in a rather simple fashion. Of course, even more sophisticated tools already seem to exist,[11] a circumstance that franky saddens and demotivates me somewhat; why arduously learn to mix paints, when one can get better results with a MATLAB/Octave script? Does one have to use all available tools to not be disadvantaged? I mentioned Dall-E2 in the last painting related post, since then more advanced ML/AI tools like Stable Diffusion were released; I have to accept that the clock can not be turned back; resistance to zeitgeist is futile after all.

Techne

I do not want to make the impression that my act of painting is actually well conceived, or as portentous as the writing would make you believe. I needlessly burden myself with an earnest sense of duty to improve my painting, because I rely on it a little too much for my self-esteem, but else it is just a rewarding, and even sporadically relaxing endeavor.

The coastal, breezy atmosphere I was looking for was well replicated from the reference in this painting, the partially blurred environment reflects itself in, and dictates the subject’s impression, rather than the other way around, while not taking away the beholder’s attention from the details presented in the foreground. The photograph might not show it, but my continuous efforts to improve the color gamut of my paintings paid off and the color accuracy improved. I first tried to mix the greens with Phthalo Green Blue Shade PG7, but it looked artificially intense for scrubs exposed to a scorching summer sun. A mixture of Cerulian PB35 and Winsor Yellow PY74 worked well. Sized at just 40⨯30cm, the scene’s depiction demanded some sacrifices in accuracy, however adjustments to the foreground details beyond this point may have been noticable on a photograph, but under normal lighting conditions and a reasonable distance the perceptible in-person quality is fine.

Even in a single blade of grass
the cool breeze
finds a home

—ISSA4

I changed my varnishing process, because my gamvar was used up. I switched to Schmincke retouching varnish, because it allows the layering of a final picture varnish, I felt would be beneficial for archival purposes, as opposed to just using gamvar. By letting the paint cure for four weeks after the final adjusting brushstrokes, the application of the retouching varnish resulted in a recognizably superior color revitalization compared to gamvar. Possible explanations for this discrepancy include time- and surface-conditioned fading of gamvar’s gloss effect property, or the inadequacy of a singular gamvar application layer; the latter could be resolved, but is just as inconvenient as the former. Considering the archival adequacy of final picture varnish, and its supposedly improved quality over the retouching varnish, waiting a few weeks is certainly worth it. Even with very thin paint layers, the minor lifting of paint due to the Naphtha (white spirit) base in Schmincke retouching varnish was not a big issue.

Endnotes

[1] J. Tschichold, The New Typography. University of California Press, 2006.

[2] G. W. Bertram, S. Deines, and D. M. Feige, Die Kunst und die Künste: Ein Kompendium zur Kunsttheorie der Gegenwart. Suhrkamp Verlag, 2021.

[3] T. W. Adorno, Ästhetische Theorie. Suhrkamp Verlag, 1973.

[4] C. J. Peariso, “Styleless Style? What Photorealism Can Tell Us about ‘the Sixties’,” J. Am. Stud., vol. 47, no. 3, pp. 743–757, Aug. 2013, doi: 10.1017/S0021875812002071. [Online]. Available: https://www.cambridge.org/core/product/identifier/S0021875812002071/type/journal_article. [Accessed: Jul. 03, 2022]

[5] E. Pricco, Juxtapoz Hyperreal. Gingko Press, 2014.

entry.title: Document Design
entry.content:
As the title suggests, the following is about interacting with different types of text based formats and how one should prepare documents so they can fulfill their functions. This is the follow-up to the Information Management post.

Once a piece of nonfiction is written based on collected information, one should give due consideration to copyediting with style guidelines like “The Chicago Manual of Style” by the University of Chicago Press[1], “The Elements of Style” by William Strunk Jr.[2] and “The Economist Style Guide” by Ann Wroe[3] for consistent quality in writing.

Choice of Format

A document refers to an object, which stores information that serve as a record. Accessability of information is thereby the primary function of documentation. Different means of access require different modes of presentation. Starting from the most adaptable format, plain text, based on the intended function of the document, one can choose a fitting format for proceeding with refining the type and layout. A good combination of markup languages is LaTeX for PDFs and html+css for WWW or EPUB, both complementarily compensating each others shortcomings, henceforward I would like to focus my deliberations on those.

The plain text document base still requires a minimum of markup, with markdown and org-mode1 being the most prominent lightweight markup languages. At this stage, the document is not for public sharing, but certain standards like proper citations should be considered to serve as a useful source later on. A good fit is the pandoc document converter software, with extensible conversion operations to LaTeX and html+css from its pandoc flavored markdown specification. Markdown documents can be initialized with a YAML metadata block to denote the author, date and title. By using the extended pandoc markdown syntax, sources can be cited from a biblatex file with [@CiteKey] and a .csl citation style file; further footnotes may be added by [^Key], immensely reducing the amount of adjustments and typesetting required to produce reasonable results for both LaTeX and html based formats from a single text. The raw_attribute extension allows conversion format conditional text blocks. The pandoc output can be improved with custom regular expression substitutions pre and post conversion, for example in python with a the subprocess and re standard libraries. Though compromises have to be made by adhering to this smallest common denominator of a simple markdown syntax, it ensures a quicker workflow and is a good starting point for more refined typesetting later on.

Most documents will benefit from including vector graphics and diagrams as pictorial, yet abstract, representations of information. Graph drawing tools include inkscape, graphviz, diagrams.net and PGF/TikZ.

In this Figure we see the following:

  1. By not using the --template option for generating a PDF in pandoc, but inputting the generated .tex files as mainmatter, a regular LaTeX document template can be used and adjusted. A batch file is used to remove the aux files of each post’s standalone PDF document. In addition, a combined document with all posts is created.

  2. Converted to markdown_strict, the generated document will work with the markdown based static site generator.

  3. Multiple bibliography files can be merged and entry inclusion be filtered by post association to keep this main bibliography up to date. The title field needs to be protected by curly brackets, because pandoc’s --citeproc conversion from biblatex to Citation Style Language metadata disregards the title case. It also does not work properly with CJK field content.

  4. Pandoc’s --template option is used to prepare the output file for inclusion in the LaTeX template in the next step with the metadata from the input file’s yaml header.

  5. A python script is executed via shell functions that convert the inputs into standalone PDFs, EPUBs and a static website.

  6. This is where one has to write the text, while adhering to a style guide.

  7. The EPUB format uses --mathml for formulas, and lua filters to maintain the correct image path across all formats

PDF Template

Template version 2023–02–26 source— ZIP

For PDF generation, LaTeX and its document classes enable the design of many types of documents from books, presentations and articles, to letters, flashcards or curriculum vitae.2

The mainly used template of mine can adapt to different design requirements, by alteration of the document structure based on assigned boolean inputs for conditional statements in the main document.

\documentclass[]{this_class}
\newcommand\true{1}

%------------------------------------------------
%   Document layout (0=false 1=true)
%------------------------------------------------
\newcommand\conditionA{0}

\usepackage{style} 

%------------------------------------------------
%   Document structure
%------------------------------------------------
\begin{document}

\ifx\conditionA\true
    \input{contentA}
\else
    \input{contentB}
\fi

\end{document}

A good document viewer for the output PDF is SumatraPDF, because it allows you to change the background and text color for reading in low light conditions.

The LaTeX template has multiple cover options. Lightweight options are maketitle for short documents, the titlepage environment, or inputting an external background and writing on top of it with the eso-pic and textpos packages.

A simple titlepage is the best option for most extensive documents, but if you want to make a bound print copy of your text, you are best served by a proper book cover including a spine. LaTeX might not be the best option for most styles of cover artwork and one would be better served with a vector graphics editor like inkscape, but covers reminiscent of the New Typography movement could certainly be created without too much of a hassle.3 It becomes clear why that is, if we consider the history of typography.

The 15th century saw the invention of the printing press, imitating the medieval handwritten manuscript design and black letter typeface. Around the turn of the century in Italy, antiqua typefaces (roman and italic type) where developed with printing in mind, increasing the bodytext’s fluency. Italian Renaissance culture spread throughout Europe by impetus of the Italian wars from 1494 to 1559 and saw innovations by the French, like Garamond. The popularity of antiqua initiated the subsequent design of Fraktur in Germany, a mellowed but as the name suggests, still distinctly fractured black letter typeface. The cultural influence of the French Rococo, sealed the transition towards French antiqua as the dominant class of typefaces across most of Europe. Clear and simple forms and the contrast in stroke thickness of French antiqua types prompt a logical progression in step with the themes of Enlightenment in the 17th and 18th centuries. Modern roman typefaces from Didot employ mathematical precision and geometric shapes. The Industrial Revolution in the 19th century spawned new production processes. The need for flashy, “grotesque” display and advertisement fonts along with trends in modern art, makes sans serif a popular alternative to antiqua in a broadening array of use cases. 1920s’ New Typography movement is a reactive response to late 19th century Art nouveau inspired printing, considered retrogressive due to its reintroduction of ornaments, by modernist typographers like Jan Tschichold, Herbert Bayer and László Moholy-Nagy.

“The essence of the New Typography is clarity. This puts it into deliberate opposition to the old typography whose aim was”beauty” and whose clarity did not attain the high level we require today. ” — The New Typography by Jan Tschichold 1928, p.66 4

I consider TeX to be a consistent progression of this mentality, but focusing less on merely exposing a printed pieces essential function, and more on providing the designer with a toolset to convey their message, allowing for a sliver of artistic expression. Even Tschichold himself repudiated his books intolerant and strict claim to absoluteness after reconsidering his cultural bias in light of World War II.

When the document is about to be printed, the printing company will provide the required cover measurements based on their production process and the selected paper thickness. Consider that the inner margin of long documents may have to be increased due to folding. The spine should follow ISO-6357 according to which the text should run from top to bottom, when the book is upright.

This design mainly utilizes the bookcover, xcoffins and tikz packages and imitates, in parts, the 1925 issue “sonderheft elementare typografie” of the magazine “typografische mitteilungen”, based on an exemplary implementation.5

Webpage Template

The html+css style for the World Wide Web should be somewhat congruent with the LaTeX template. The static site generator takes pandoc’s output markdown files, executes the conversion to html and applies the template accordingly. As html+css is not agnostic to the document viewer’s dimensions, insisting on ideal replication is both unfeasible and unnecessary. It’s adaptability requires new guidelines; for example, whereas in PDF’s there is no need to strip images of their metadata individually, images included in html documents should be examined with exiftool prior to publication. I find that justified text does not look pleasing on websites, the interword spacing is often distracting. As this website is build by the static site generator jekyll utilizing the minima theme, most of the publication design is determined by modifications to the predefined settings.[8] After quite a few iterations, I now gladly consider this publication design congruent with its intended function. Notably, the orthographic best practices are independent of format and are applicable to all documents. When in doubt, my reference of choice is the “Chicago Manual of Style” since even the best template requires copyediting.

As German law demands legal information such as legal notices and data privacy policies to be constantly and easily accessible from every subpage, integrating them in the global website footer is most convenient. In the _includes folder, add contact.html in Liquid syntax to the theme’s footer.html and create those files. In contact.html just add assets/pages/contact.md in Liquid syntax, and create that path. With permalink: /contact/ in the document yaml-head, the legal notice will be build and linked correctly.

I added custom sub- and superscript css properties to eliminate line spacing irregularities caused by endnotes.

//custom: eliminate line spacing irregularities
sup {
  vertical-align: super; 
  line-height: 1ex;
}

sub {
  vertical-align: sub;
  line-height: 1ex;
}

I also added a use_math: true/false YAML field, only loading mathjax when needed. Mathjax’s CSS container mjx-container should be changed to overflow-x: auto; for display math and overflow-x: hidden; for inline math mjx-container:not([display]), else the layout breaks with long equations and unneeded scrollbars.

EPUB Template

For comfortable offline reading on screens, a pandoc conversion to EPUB is a good option. EPUB is an open source, XML based format that supports both fixed and reflowable layout formatting and a subset of MathML; in effect, such a file is an archive that contains a website. For most types of electronic publications, EPUB should be superior to PDF since the content can be processed and extracted, for example with regular expressions.

Endnotes

[1] University of Chicago Press, The Chicago Manual of Style, 17th ed. University of Chicago Press.

[2] W. Strunk, The Elements of Style. 1918.

[3] A. Wroe, The Economist Style Guide.

[4] H. Voß, Einführung in LaTeX.

[5] M. Öchsner and A. Öchsner, Advanced LaTeX In Academia. 2022.

[6] J. Tschichold, The New Typography. University of California Press, 2006.

[7] M. J. Krysinski, The Art of Type and Typography: Explorations in Use and Practice.

[8] T. Preston-Werner, “Blogging Like a Hacker,” Nov. 17, 2008. [Online]. Available: https://tom.preston-werner.com/2008/11/17/blogging-like-a-hacker.html

  1. Emacs org-mode has the benefit, that it includes an export functionality for both html and LaTeX, but for me it would mean a reimplementation of a process I have already optimized, and a new dependancy. The conversion will not result in a document as tailored to my preferences as writing native TeX or html myself; furthermore markdown is in braod use in other applications, i.e. this page’s static site generator jekyll. ↩

  2. The best resource for TeX related information is tex.stackexchange.com. For a more structured approach, I can recommend “Einführung in LaTeX” (german) by Herbert Voß[4] and “Advanced LaTeX In Academia Applications In Research And Education” by Marco Öchsner and Andreas Öchsner[5]. The latter offers up-to-date ideas and implementations, especially relevant for teachers and students in higher education. Because the included code snippets are displayed with line numbers, they are not easily copyable, the inclusion of the document source with attachfile, or linking to it with a QR code would have been helpful. ↩

  3. As LaTeX is a non-visual editor, describing complex shapes is cumbersome; all measurements are based on the unit sp with $1pt = \frac{1}{65536}sp \approx 2.845mm$. Larger units too can only be seperated into 65536 parts. Regardless of unit choosen, the 5th decimal place is thus always the most precise. ↩

  4. “The New Typography” by Jan Tschichold[6] reads contemporary despite being written around 100 years ago (1928). What would not surprise me with classic fiction, feels surprising for non fiction. The choice of vocabulary can be unexpected at times as the German author uses seemingly anglicised German words that must have either been more canonical English words back then, or the suitable terms were unascertainable, which is equally peculiar from a modern standpoint. “The Art of Type and Typography” by Mary Jo Krysinski[7] is a modern introduction to typography. Intended as supplementary textbook for the “Beginning Typography” class at The School of the Art Institute of Chicago, there are both assignments and a heavy focus on the usage of Adobe® InDesign® software. Among my learnings is the use of small-caps, as to not interfere with the overall font weight distribution when using abbreviations. My favorite fonts include “Consolas”, a monospaced sans serif font I use in text editors; “Futura”, developed based on geometric shapes in 1928 by German artist and designer Paul Renner and “Computer Modern Bright”, part of the Computer Modern family of typefaces designed by Donald Knuth. ↩

  5. It is based on user michal.h21’s answer at https://tex.stackexchange.com/a/17580. ↩
