entry.title: Painting 2
entry.content:
I henceforth set out on a quest to find for myself an acceptable definition of how art mechanistically functions, a reembarkment in lieu of my conviction that likely no satisfactory conclusion exists.

Thoughts on Painting, Again

It seems to be a given, that artworks have certain qualities, which are desired by their onlookers, prompting the production of paintings with the goal to profit from said desires.1 Commissions and reproductions are preceded by a market demand, making the production less risky for the artist. A driver of value for original work is evidently it’s uniqueness, or as proxy for that the risk of the investment into it’s creation, as one can not be sure the work or style will be desired, thus the market discounts the value of replicas based on the available information it possesses about the risk reduction.

Paintings with realistic motive are limited in their stylistic choices cuing both commonness and risk reduction, hence value is mainly generated by the time invested and technical ability required from the creator, a proof-of-work approach in an attempt to assert intrinsic value. The advent of photography in the 1830s meant paintings liberation from it’s representative function enabling a purely abstract use of the medium.[1] The photorealist movement of the 1970s can be seen as a successful renaissance, not only because of the proof-of-work aspect noted above, but also thanks to the unexpected—dare I say pointless—embracement of this style at that time, since the supposed goal of modern painting was thought to be, as described in Charles Baudelaire’s “Painter of Modern Life”, the “ability to create a world that distills the eternal from the transatory”. Advancements in artificial intelligence, new resources and tooling for traditional and digital art, simplifying the creation workflow, cause their perceived value qua invested resources to decrease over time in regards to the aforementioned indicators; a valuation subject to inflation which can only be counteracted by historic significance of the object.2

But this empirically observable “value market” is not informationally efficient; the demand is only minorly based on available, somewhat quantifiable information, or the artist’s “risk” of production; the object’s value largely correlates with the subjective onlooker’s personal taste. Due to it’s nature as an object sought for aesthetic appeal, the derivation of general laws of taste that could explain said correlation is obviated by the “indistinguishability” definition of aesthetic properties by Mary Mothersill.

“The aesthetic properties of an individual O are those that define the class of items which, for a particular subject, S, under standard conditions, etc., are indistinguishable from O”

This contradicts Thomas Aquinas’s definition of beauty. He claims “beauty is not a concept in the mind of the beholder imposed onto a given object”, as “beauty resides in the object.”, making beauty a quantifiable measure.3 But, de gustibus non est disputandum. Would it not take a dualistic approach in the perception of beauty to explain the difficulty of taste consensus-building? Would one not have to allow for a subject’s predisposition; a subjective element in the cognition of beauty? The following quote from “Image and Insight”[3] explores this idea “the object of pleasure (the painting) is noncontingently related to the subject’s pleasure”, before referring to Freud’s theory that objects (of pleasure) can only be refound.

Ellen Handler Spitz then goes one step further and meets Horst Bredekamp with his Bildakt theory.[4] We now consider the art-object to act as a subject, interacting with the thusly beheld subject in this transactional model. Such approach “locates aesthetic pleasure in the subject (and) also in a dynamic in which the spectator-subject may become object to the aesthetic subject qua subject.”[3]

You could be led to belief, that the painter of the object is a mere bystander in this model, but au contraire it is said that “a viewer can identify with the artist’s unconscious desires expressed through sublimation”[5] via the painting. The aesthetic subject is shaped by, and serves as a “means of giving expression to, and dealing with, various psychic pressures”4 of the artist. Maybe like a child relates to their parents, the creation is both an independent entity as well as a reflection of it’s creator’s inner workings. As someone who has had a tendency for perfectionism in painting matters, the parable constructed ex supra is calming. Your responsibility is limited, at some point it is on the painting and the spectator to find each other.

Another Painting

The time I can allocate to painting in it’s function as an end in itself pastime is sadly limited. I can’t help but have a sense of urgency, making productive use of my time painting, on the rare occasion the prerequisites of sufficient time and right mood are fulfilled. It is imperative that I know about challenges likely to arise, and that I don’t lose interest due to complications and delays, as it takes a long time to complete, even without them. I am hesitant to alter my motive too drastically, though I will look for some new aspects that I can introduce to expand my repertoire.

This time around, among these new aspects is a renewed focus on high contrast imagery, i.e. sizable areas near the black- and white-point. I think the improvements are more noticeable in person, the photographs taken are still not entirely satisfactory. If I compare these photos with ones taken of other’s paintings, I can’t fathom how great they must look in person, though my work’s small dimensions could have a lot to do with this.

Another obvious novelty is the facial expression, the lag of opened eyes as a point of orientation and the inclusion of laughter lines were the main new challenges this time around.

Python-fu Function Experiment

Mentioning points of orientation, I have recently experimented with gimp’s python-fu functionality to create a routine called “outlined” that could create a characteristic outline of an image for usage as a fast, transferable underdrawing template generator. I should mention that I have yet to use this procedure—likely will never—for any project, because now that I see it’s output, I’m convinced it would not be helpful, even with lots of manual adjustments, remotely as much as I would like it to. My main goal was to get familiar with python and gimp, and that I accomplished; I only share it here to show off some dead ends in my process of creating paintings, and because it took me a long time to write.
This proposed function could have improved the process of painting from a reference image, but as declared ex supra, it would also beg the question at what point the artist becomes a servant to the computer’s calculations.

The quote “The Photo-Realist uses the camera and photograph to gather information. The Photo-Realist uses a mechanical or semi-mechanical means to transfer the information to the canvas.”, is part of the definition of Photorealists by Louis K. Meisel from 1972. As we are now further along the Digital Age timeline, the helpful tools for Computer-aided digital image to photorealistic oil painting reproduction assistance have advanced qua the introduction of image processing software; potentially providing the painter with data points about color pigment mixing and placement optimizations. Should all available tools be used to create the envisioned end product, or should the end product be valued based on the assistance it received as it was created?

After some searching, the above image [7] resulted in the best output. What I noticed is that, because the outlining happens in a for-loop, the outline is applied to the outlineless image for each iteration. This would not be possible without a script, as the standart border selection tool in the Gui would work with the partly outlined image for each subsequent color, resulting in outlined area borders with twice the thickness.

The following use-caseless code, for Windows, is located at ...\AppData\Roaming\GIMP\2.10\plug-ins as outlined.py.

[2] M. R. Spicher, “Medieval Theories of Aesthetics.” [Online]. Available: https://iep.utm.edu/medieval-theories-of-aesthetics/#SH3c. [Accessed: Nov. 01, 2022]

[3] E. H. Spitz, Image and Insight: Essays in Psychoanalysis and the Arts. 1991.

[4] J. Wiebicke and M. Gabriel, “WDR 5 Das philosophische Radio: Machtvoll? - Kunstwerke.” Apr. 04, 2022 [Online]. Available: https://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/wdr5/wdr5-das-philosophische-radio/audio-machtvoll---kunstwerke-100.html

[7] ArtHouse Studio, “Pexels: Experienced Mongolian Male Rider in Prairie,” 2019. [Online]. Available: https://www.pexels.com/photo/experienced-mongolian-male-rider-in-prairie-4321509/

    For years, there has been a trend in digital painting to create “smudge paintings”, impacting digital painting photorealists. After importing a digital image, brush tools are used to create a likeness to digital paintings, as if the slightly altered image had been created from scratch—influencing the value proposition. ↩

  4. “Every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of the artist, not of the sitter.”, is a quote from Oscar Wilde’s “The Picture of Dorian Gray” [6] and despite not entirely fitting this texts argumentation, the book is still recommended for readers interested in the subject of painting. entry.title: Thoughts on Strength Sport
entry.content:
This is not a conclusive chain of reasoning, rather an attempt to shed light upon the justifications that constitute a particular lifestyle, with close attention paid to hindering mock-over-intellectualization.

“It is a rather risky matter to discuss a happiness that has no need of words.” ― Yukio Mishima, Sun and Steel1 [1]

Presuppose you are toying with the somewhat existentialist idea, that the goal in life is to find a way to distract yourself from the fact, that there is—at least inherently—no meaning.2 With that said, the ability to choose ‘distracting’ activities you declare meaningful substantiates why striving for physical health is more fulfilling than spending your time in a restricted, unwell state. The special eurobarometer survey on sport and physical activity in the Eu[5], finds that the share of people who never participate in sport has increased over the past years to almost 50%, alleging that a lag of time and interest are the leading causes, while health and fitness improvements, as well as relaxation are the primary motivators. Significant indicators for increased physical activity are being male, being in a younger age group, finishing formal education later in life, higher financial freedom and rural living. As long as you are able to spare some time, how can a sport’s contrived challenge foster meaning and motivate beyond the apparently insufficient, ascertained reasons by the survey? To quote the book “Introduction to the Philosophy of Sport”3 by Heather Lynne Reid.

“We begin, as Plato and Aristotle did, with an appreciation of sport’s autotelicity—the notion that it is (at least ideally) an end in itself, done for its own sake, without the need of external purpose or justification.” [6]

The autotelicity mirrors a sense of pointlessness in life, facilitating the translateability of learned in-game behavior and procedures into real life situations. You could say that a sports’ existence precedes its essence, the latter indispensably emerges through virtuous practice, as an athlete’s skill is not valuable because of the sports performance it produces, but because a skill obtained through virtue can find application, and result in good, outside the game. Advanced capacity to navigate the world around you can be a motivation to participate in sport; but admittedly, the tolerance to delayed gratification induced by autotelicity varies from person to person and few people will be convinced by the declared line of arguments alone, to start lifting weights. With this type of physical activity there is a more straightforward reason that comes to mind, improving outward appearance. At this point, I would like to make another lemma, a distinction between sports focused on performance and those focused on aesthetics, namely bodybuilding.

“Aesthetics is incidental in sport, whereas, in art, it is the principal aim. Therefore, sport is not an art.” [7]

With regard to the categorization via the quote ex supra, bodybuilding’s artistic dimension directly—at times involuntarily—signals virtuous behavior even outside the game, amplifying the motivation for athletes, but also potentiating social pressures; as art concerns something beyond itself, the onlooker naturally cues self-reflection and self-projection. Many struggle with exposure to virtue signaling via social media and the way its recommendation algorithms create an expectation, foremost damning to the mental health of teenagers; giving rise to body dysmorphic disorder.4 [9] When this reduces your scope of possible actions one could declare meaningful, because you feel that you can never miss your session, or can exclusively eat “clean”, then your fitness plays too big of a role—keeping everything in balance is imperative. The most rational way to curb discontent, either way, is demystification and relativization of achievements, concluding in a simple cost–benefit analysis. Fulfillment depends on what you truly desire, as opposed to what you want to want. Notwithstanding the above, as aging societies suffer from a lag of caregivers for elders, improving fitness to reduce care needs is made out as a core philosophy in geriatric nursing5; the pressure to become, or stay fit will only increase for all age groups.

Radical Ideas

This is easier said than done, as even rational, scientifically minded practitioners rely on creating a grand narrative for temporarily improved performance and motivational purposes.

“I have been thinking of food as an input output system for so long, I think, how can they do that with no purpose? The only way in this time in my life, that I can see myself, is an input output machine. Input nutrients, training, supplements, etc.; output objective, quantifiable performance and body composition measures. That’s it. That is the only thing that makes sense.”— Mike Israetel 6

Corine Pelluchon in her book “Les Nourritures: philosophie du corps politique”7 specifies living as “living via [nutrition]”, unveiling a human’s fundamental dependency from food and the ethic responsibility towards the environment as its origin. Under this premise, can purposeful eating in the above quoted manner be considered ethical?

Yukio Mishima, in his 1968 essay “Sun and Steel”,[1] supports this line of thinking with, as can be expected from him, radicality. He goes as far as to say, that imperfect “physical individuality”—necessarily also including improper nutrition—are narcissistic and an act of “shameless indecency”. He further recognizes the applicability of what is labeled as “progressive overload” in modern exercise science for both classically ideal conceptualizations of exercise and education, setting forth the importance of balance between action(body) and word(thought); a corporeality of the subject. His thought is only concerned about individualized well-being and a sense of superiority through physical supremacy. While this opinion is regrettably prevalent in some circles, more often it is assumed by non-practitioners that everyone engaged in sport activities thinks in such ways.

Strength Sports Literature Review

There is really no point in restating what has been said better hundreds of times before. I just want to highlight some a posteriori insights about resources regarding this topic, as the sheer amount of information available depresses the navigableness by a fair margin. Do not miss the forest for the trees.

  • You Are Your Own Gym: The Bible of Bodyweight Exercises - Joshua Clark & Mark Lauren - 2011 [13]
    • You can get surprisingly far without a gym if you are a beginner; hypertrophic training in this manner is beneficial to strength training later on
    • Invaluable during a pandemic or on holiday trips
  • Scientific Principles of Hypertrophy Training - Mike Israetel et al. [14]
    • The structure and style of writing in this book is in accordance to what you would want your hypertrophy training to look like; very comprehensible, no junk volume
    • It is not an academic text, but I think it is a good starting point for science-based deepening of one’s knowledge
    • The book “Science and Development of Muscle Hypertrophy” by Brad Schoenfeld is a more formal resource on hypertrophy
  • Scientific Principles of Strength Training - Mike Israetel - 2015 [15]
    • The above applies, but the hypertrophy book feels more well-rounded
  • Olympic Weightlifting - Greg Everett - 2008 [16]
    • Good book on weightlifting, but video is without a doubt a superior format for weightlifting movement demonstration
  • 5/3/1 Forever - Jim Wendler - 2017 [17]
    • Jim Wendler, in his 5/3/1-book series, outlines programs based on nothing but his own anecdotal evidence. While I’m not fond of the author and his methodology, this book sets realistic expectations and specifies requirements concluding a well-rounded strength building program.
    • This practical blueprint aligns with a surprising amount of scientific research conducted and detailed in some of the other books
  • Power to the People - Pavel Tsatsouline - 1999 [18]
    • you are in a pandemic, sports equipment supply is running low and you only have a barbell and weights? This program is worth a try
  • Glute Lab: The Art and Science of Strength and Physique Training - Bret Contreras [19]
    • Other books give a more structured approach and the main selling point of this one seems to be the glute focal point including the invention of the barbell hip thrust, which I personally do not find to be a good exercise, so I would not recommend the book
  • Science and Practice of Strength Training - Vladimir M. Zatsiorsky et al. [20]
    • I particularity like the chapters on strength training for specific populations, good to know for advising referenced groups of people

While people try to science their way out of hard work in training, they are inclined to go beyond scientific consensus in the fad prone field of nutrition in their quest for shortcuts, or mis/over-interpret findings and fall for micronutrient reductionism.

  • The Muscle and Strength Training Pyramid: Nutrition - Eric Helms - 2018 [21]
    • A comprehensive, but thanks to its importance-sorted structure, applicable text with references for more detailed inquiries
    • The author is part of the MASS (Monthly Applications in Strenght Sport) research review
  • Essentials of Sports Nutrition and Supplements - Jose Antonio - 2008 [22]
    • Definitive textbook that may or may not be outdate in parts

Fatigue accumulated during exercise has to be recovered to ensure muscular adaptation to training load and is an integral part of the training process.

  • Stretching Anatomy - Arnold G. Nelson & Jouko Kokkonen - 2006 [23]
    • The anatomy aspect of the book is more interesting than the stretching, because you get a feel for movement ranges and patterns via the illustrations
    • I suppose more stretching can’t hurt and is advisable for most
    • post-exercise static stretching can be a method to reduce perceived fatique
  • Why We Sleep - Matthew Walker - 2018 [24]
    • adequate sleep is the best recovery strategy

This may be tangentially related to strength sport, but consider preventive health screenings and stress management. As a closing remark, remember that the pinnacle of non-professional sports is not to have your life revolve around it, but to incorporate sport successfully into your daily life to enhance it.

entry.title: Painting
entry.content:
A painting has two major aspects to it, the artistic and the craftsmanship dimension.[1] Whereas the proficiency of the respective artwork is a fairly quantifiable measure, artistic value is a product of personal preference and the societal system of values forming one’s personal viewpoint.

The Value of Painting

Authentic Art opposes norms and introduces a transcendental perspective, a line of thought that could be taken to reveal the lag of value in the uniform output of the culture industry [Kulturindustrie].

“Standardisierten und identischen Waren ausgeliefert, entwickeln die Konsumenten die vom System „gewünschten“ Bedürfnisse.” — [2]

The capitalist dogma of profit maximization compels the industry to deliver addicting, hence instantaneously pleasurable products to the widest audience possible, rendering them docile as the desired is repeatedly exposed, mutilating one’s capacity to value and create non-standartized art.

“Kulturindustrie sublimiert nicht sondern unterdrückt.” — [3]

Sublimation would indeed be difficult to achieve; qua establishment of a noise floor for the psychological drives, exposure to culture industrial goods should render ex nihilo creation of art impossible. Through capitalism’s ability to accommodate various forms of resistance, opposition to the mainstream only validates the status quo, makes authentic art an accomplice chained to what it negates.

“Sometimes doing nothing is the most violent thing to do” — [4], [5]

Reproductions of master’s works can have meaning as a comment on the commodification of art itself, combining craftsmanship with the distinct minimization of personal artistic involvement by the artist.

Romanticized views attribute art the function of a deeper form of communication; a special form of expression by the painter. Painting can certainly behave like diary writing, the language used however is your very own, not to be taken verbatim, as all meaning and value is derived from the viewer’s perspective. Thus, a reproduction or copy of a painting can have the same perceived value as an authentic artwork, even if the value system from where it is judged is flawed.

“Painting is just another form of keeping a diary” — [6]

My Painting

With the distinctions made ex supra,1 I am content with the fact, that this painting inheres a lower artistic value and meaning for me than some of my other paintings. Maybe take it as a comment on Kulturindustie, or something. This is probably also the reason I dislike sharing this work with others less, it just does not feel as personal/private as some others do.

The craftsmanship, with this painting only having $40\text{cm}\times30\text{cm}$ measurements and the degree of detail, proportions and reasonability of colors given, is pleasing. The paint layer is very thin and comprises of a acrylic underlayer based on the underdrawing, plotting out the different areas of similar scenery with a rough average color. Then introducing the full spectrum of detail in the second layer, and adjusting and highlighting further in the third. Factors that lead the uppermost paint layer to retain wet paint characteristics for longer, should increase in subsequent layers. This rule in mind, I increased the oil amount of the paint accordingly.

The biggest technical mistake I made with this painting, is not oiling out the jawline before reworking the area at one point. The strands of hair overlapping with the sky have a rugged texture; because I do not use any solvents as the core feature is quick dissipation making ventilation or respiratory mask use necessary, the paint’s plasticity is rather stiff. Only after varnishing did I notice, that the left eye highlight seems somewhat washed out and that the introduction of dust into the paint and varnish layer is minimal, but more than i would have liked.

Photographing the painting was a challenge in itself and I am still on the lookout for possible optimizations in the process. After varnishing the painting with Gamvar, every bit of impasto refracts and reflects the light. This image is the closest representation for now, it differs somewhat when seen tête-à-tête.

This is a list of products I used for this painting:

  • Winsor & Newton Artists’ Oil Colours; reliable properties [7]
    • French Ultramarine pb29
    • Cadmium Red pr108
    • Cadmium Yellow py35
    • Burned Umber pBr7
    • Ivory Black pBk9
    • Titanium White pw6
    • Cerulean Blue pb35 (only sky)
    • Yellow Ochre py43 (only background)
    • Winsor Yellow py74 (only sky)
  • brushes
    • daVinci nova synthetics 1570, 3/0,10/0
    • Princeton, Series P3750, grainer size 1/4”
    • Princeton, Series P3750, mini bristle fan size 20/0
    • Princeton, Series P3750, round blender size 6
    • varnishing brush
  • Sennelier #Greenforoils Oil Brush Cleaner
    • brush washing bucket
  • artisti Brush soap
  • MDF panels, boesner Gesso Malplatte
    • a long term goal is making the panels myself
  • Winsor & Newton tear-off palettes, 29⨯21 cm
    • I can just throw away the palette when I am done for the day, no cleaning required
  • magnifying spectacles
  • palette knife, Zank 1001
  • linseed oil
    • medium drying time with little discoloration; maybe not ideal for very light areas
  • lintfree cloth
  • chopstick holder, used for brushes
  • pipette, used for portioning oil
  • clove essential oil
    • as it has anti-oxidant properties, keeping it next to your palette in an air-tight container will lead to drying retardation [8]
    • cotton pads for clove oil
    • palette container
  • fine sand paper
    • the idea is to keep the paint planar, have rarely used it to date
  • workbench lamp, Komerci KML-9505CCT 30W LED
    • helpful for details and painting at night
  • paper towels
  • Gamvar
    • varnishing
  • transfer paper
    • I do my sketch on paper and transfer it once I am happy, because drawing and erasing on the panels has the potential to introduce too many particles that interact with my thin paint layers
  • zip lock bag
    • for used paper towels, so I can dispose of them in bulk

Endnotes

[1] E. Fromm, The Art of Loving. 1956.

[2] U. H. Bittlingmayer, A. Demirović, and T. Freytag, Handbuch Kritische Theorie. 2019.

[3] M. Horkheimer and T. W. Adorno, Dialektik der Aufklärung. 1944.

[4] The Dangerous Maybe, “I Would Prefer Not To: Žižek’s Bartleby Politics,” Jan. 29, 2019. [Online]. Available: https://thedangerousmaybe.medium.com/i-would-prefer-not-to-žižeks-bartleby-politics-12bd8d9de66a

[5] S. Zizek, Violence: Six Sideways Reflections. 2008.

[6] P. Picasso, “Painting is just another way of keeping a diary.” [Online]. Available: https://www.goodreads.com/quotes/163896-painting-is-just-another-way-of-keeping-a-diary

[7] B. Edwards, Color: A Course in Mastering the Art of Mixing Colors.

[8] G. O’Hanlon, “Clove Oil in Painting,” Jun. 10, 2013. [Online]. Available: https://www.naturalpigments.eu/artist-materials/clove-oil-paint?___store=naturalpigmentseu

  1. Considering [1], is the process of learning an art different from practicing an art, insofar as it does not require an artistic vision; that it is only applied theory? “The process of learning an art can be divided conveniently into two parts; one, the mastery of the theory; the other, the mastery of the practice.”. The words ‘art’ and ‘craftsmanship’ could be used interchangeably. ↩

entry.title: Drawing
entry.content:
Drawing has been the most efficient way to communicate visual ideas for centuries. From traditional instruments such as charcoal, to modern digital drawing software, the simple act of toning a surface with media to approximate the visual world is critical from visual arts, architecture, design, to engineering.

In distinction to painting, drawing involves dry media, with pastels bridging the gap towards the liquid media, like acrylic and oil paints. Drawing with its minimal equipment required to produce meaningful work, more so than painting, enables artistic expression within every milieu.

Detour: Vertigo (1958)

Alfred Hitchcock, depicted in the accompaning drawing, is someone I first encountered by reading the books and listening to the taped versions of the popular juvenile detective book series “Alfred Hitchcock and the Three Investigators” as a child, or rather their German translation.[1] Years later, my interest in film swiftly brought be back to the “Master of Suspense”. Hitchcock’s Vertigo is not only objectively one of the best movies, but coincidentally also one of my personal favourites.

Retired, acrophobic detective Scottie (James Stewart) is asked by Gavin Elster, an old friend, to follow his wife named Madeleine Elster (Kim Novak), as she seems to strangely identify herself with Carlotta, a relative of hers who commited suicide. Scottie and Madeleine fall in love, but as she too commits suicide by jumping of a mission’s tower, Scottie gets depressed, descents into madness and tries to find Madeleine by frequenting places she has been to, noticing a woman named Judy. The viewer learns that this woman is “Madeleine” and was hired to act as Gavin’s wife to cover-up a murder, exploiting Scotties fear of heights. Scottie keeps wanting Judy to resemble Madeleine, but soon notices her necklace that is also shown on a painting of Carlotta, uncovering the scheme. He wants to drive her back to the alledged suicide scene, where he then finally overcomes his vertigo. As the two admit their love for each other, the story ends tragically as Judy falls to her death by accident.

This story leaves us with parallels between the characters; while at first glance, Scottie seems to be the victim of a murder cover-up scheme initiated by Gavin Elster and Judy, Scottie progressively becomes similar to Gavin, as he too objectifies Judy in order to realize his dream, oblivious to her infatuation for him. It would be easy to sympathize with Kim Novak’s Judy, as the sport of misfortune she is, tragically falling in love with a man who longs only for a woman that has never been real, then later falling to her own death; but didn’t she have it coming by tricking Scottie and taking money to cover up a crime?

Hitchcock’s female lead actors usually do not radiate this pleasant ambiguity, making Vertigo suspenseful by letting the viewer feel uncomfortable regardless of their own interpretation, or allegiance.

Now let’s get back to the point.1

Drawing of Alfred Hitchcock

The reason for this motive is not that I like Vertigo so much, in reality I just wanted to draw an older man with wrinkles and many opportunities to introduce sharp detail in order to conveniently create a realistic look. While I value the craftsmanship aspects of drawing, I do not wish to lose all artistic interpretation.

This is a list of products I use for drawings:

  • Copic marker, N6 Neutral Grey
    • for giving the clothes an even background color; alcohol-based ink colours
  • Pentel GraphGear 1000, 0.5mm
    • primary detail mechanical pencil
  • uni POSCA PC-1MR, white
    • water-based paint marker for highlights
  • Brunnen ART ERASER
    • reliably removes charcoal and lightens areas without streaks
  • edding 780 paint marker 0.8mm, white
    • highlights; alternative to POSCA markers
  • Tombow MONO zero
    • primary detail eraser; for creating hair highlights
  • Faber-Castell Ecco Pigment, 0.05
    • fine liner for detail, darkest blacks
  • Faber-Castell Polychromos, white
    • highlights; did not work well, as it isn’t ink based
  • Faber-Castell 9000 – 4H, 2H, HB, 3B, 6B, 8B
    • primary pencil range, used 6B the most
  • Faber-Castell Perfection 7057
    • fine eraser; alternative to Tombow MONO zero
  • Stabilo point 88 fine 0.4, black
    • dark lines; alternative to Faber-Castell Ecco Pigment
  • rolled papyrus pencil smudger
    • smooth transitions
  • heavy, but fine drawing paper
    • not too thin to disintegrate during erasing, but fine as to not have visible surface texture
  • Pigma Micron
    • not sure if I used them for this, but they are my favorite pens

As can be seen in the list above, I started to incorporate ink based products, mainly to achieve higher contrast. Most high-quality ink pens and markers are manufactured in Japan by brands—often with comic book artists in mind—like Sakura Color Products, Tombow, Uni Mitsubishi Pencil, Copic and Pentel, known for popularizing the Fudepen. This certainly improved my drawings, although it technically means that the “artworks” are a mixture of drawing and painting, if we take the definitions of the first paragraph as gospel.

In retrospect I should have toned the background in a light grey, that would improve the drawing immensely. To some extent I enjoy seeing mistakes, or wrong decisions in my drawings, because only then do I have a chance to improve.

Endnotes

[1] R. Arthur, “Alfred Hitchcock mystery series.” 1964.

[2] P. Boileau and T. Narcejac, “Vertigo.” 1956.

  1. Let me just add that I read the 1954 french novel “The Living and the Dead” (original: “D’entre les morts”) by Boileau-Narcejacon the film is based on.[2] As it is set in France, a lot of the adaptation’s San Francisco atmosphere is missing and I imagine few would remember this book, if it was not for Hitchcock. I wouldn’t really recommend reading it. ↩
